This place never ceases to amaze me!! I love the coffee here! At night I find myself looking forward to waking up and getting my morning latte. The staff is always friendly, the service is fast and the baked goods are great! 
I have brought several friends here with me. It is one of my favorite spots to take people to experience the inner sunset. All of them have loved this place. They tell me how much better the coffee tastes here than anywhere else.... you know what? they are right! The coffee here is great! I am a fan for life.
author: Wes P.

description:
My friend and I were going on a trip down to Saratoga and we stopped in here to get some coffee before we left off. I really liked the fact you had a choice of coffees unlike some places which just do a 'house roast'. I chose the French Roast which I love anyway but this was particuarly nice and really smooth. 

This place is right opposite the N line so it's dead easy to get to and it's not without competition with Starbucks and a Jamba Juice across the road but it hold's it's own well. You always feel like you've stumbled across something a bit special when you pop in here and you see all the roasting equipment at the back. There's about 3 seats outside on the pavement but I didn't fancy sitting there with the Muni rattling past every couple of minutes.
author: Adam S.

description:
I like The Beanery as my local coffee shop. However, it seems that when they get busy, the employees have a hard time dealing with the orders. I was the only person ordering and I asked for my bagel with cream cheese on the side. After I paid, they suddenly got a rush of to-go orders, all of which (some bagels) were ready before mine. I went up to the counter to inquire, and the barista said off-handedly, oh yeah, here is your order. Cream cheese was slathered on it. I said, "I asked for the CC on the side." She answered "Oh I didn't catch that." And proceeded to offer me the order.
This is plain bad customer service. Cream cheese doesn't make or break my day. Had she been a little nicer, I would have taken the bagel. 
I just stared at her and she was like, "Oh, do you want a new one?" And I answered yes, just for her lack of customer service.
As a former local coffee shop barista who has handled lines of 40 customers single-handedly, I was not happy with her attitude and lack of professionalism.
author: Sara G.

description: This is another place I would go too for Coffee if I were around the Inner Sunset. I have gone here for as long as this place has been around. I don't remember when, but I do remember I have been here before for as long as I could. They serve up good coffee like many other places I have been too. But if I need some joe and i am too far out of my way from my favorite location in the same area, I would go here for sure!!
author: Jacen W.

description: I love free wifi..I love hunkering down in a cafe with my laptop and a great cappuccino..I was initially upset by the lack of outlets and wifi in this place until I realized it 1) forced me to work and not surf the net 2) read a good book instead of my laptop and 3) decompress. The cappuccino is fantastic and the staff has always been very friendly.
author: Kelly H.

description: Perfect soy caramel latte. No need to tell them half the number of pumps like at other nearby coffee shops... perfect for a caffeine fix, not a sugar high!
author: Miss H.

description:
What better way to start a morning than with a delicious latte from the Beanery? Their coffee is strong and their staff is superb. The staff remembered my order within a few days, which is very flattering and the mark of a good business--knowing your customers. 

Beanery, you make my day.
author: Tina Y.

description: Beautiful cafe, but it has no wifi, a must for a student like me. Their other location at 602 Irving does, but it's not nearly as pretty inside.
author: Juliana S.

description: Very cool, non-major chain coffee place. It's cool that you pay for the coffee, get a cup, and then choose from several brews (in pots) which one you want and dispense it yourself. The staff was friendly during my visit. In addition, this location has something that can be described as a old museum-like piece related to coffee-making as an exhibit.
author: H K.

description:
I often buy whole beans from this place and I have never been disappointed. They provide really good dark roasted coffee beans at an affordable price. It's nice to haves place that isn't obsessed with the new wave light roast coffee. For those who want their beans as fresh as possible, come on tuesday when they roast them.
Coffee made at the place is also excellent!  The only knock on the place is their pastries, they are really sub-par.
author: Mark K.

description:
This short, cherubic, sweet barista is, without a doubt, the greatest barista that I have ever had the pleasure to be serviced by.

Not like that.

*Damn you guys are sick*

This guy remembers my order every time, somehow seems to know when I want Iced Coffee, and when I want a mocha.  He will have it started before I know what he started or what I have decided.  I don't get it.  With power over time and space like that this cat is completely a humble man to stay at this shop.  

Part of my mornings in many ways... work and weekend.  I know I have turned some of my Starbucks friends on to local coffee shops because of this one.  Roasting their own beans, providing friendly, community based service...
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: great place to stop in for a coffee. it was clear that they had a bunch of regulars evidenced by the specific greetings they shouted to the people coming through the door. "hey there he is with his farmers market bag!" i like a place that has regulars. the coffee is pretty good and the people friendly.
author: Regina C.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I used to wake up extra 30 minutes early so I can get myself a organic french roast from here ,sit infront of the cafe and enjoy the beautiful morning in Inner Sunset. The staff there are gut wrenchingly friendly and warm people. Their smiles always brightened up my day. I love you Mony! 

go Beanery, go!
author: Saeko I.

description: The best made Americano I've had in SF. Great pastries. Fast and super-friendly service. And they have cool tables. Highly recommended. Don't be tempted by the Starbucks across the street!
author: B Q.

description: I like the coffee and pastries.  The espresso could fuel a jet plane!  It's a little to much for me, but please indulge if you so dare!
author: mary w.

description:
One star because they serve coffee, the elixir of my life's blood. 
One star because it is an attractive looking place when you first come in.

Only... it's also an uncomfortable place, kinda like sitting in church. The coffee is not that good, and when you get it served with an indifferent attitude, it only brings the cup further down.
author: Dixon T.

description: I'm surprised that this place has the 4-star rating it does. I was there yesterday, and I found the coffee to have a burnt flavor and was very annoyed that they only took cash. They don't even have wifi. Get with the times.
author: Louis C.

description: Finally came here for my very first time. Got a mocha and wasn't too impressed but that's probably because I like my mochas sweeter than usual. I liked that they made a foamy heart design, though. The place is small and all the tables are super close together. Will try again another day and hoping I can increase my stars!
author: Eugenia G.

description:
I decided that after having attended my yoga class over in the Richmond, that all I wanted to do was sit and read.  Really that's about all I had energy to do.

So after I came home from my class, exhausted, I took a shower, ate something and then decided I didn't want to go that far to a local cafe to read.  I remembered this place and always see loads of people getting coffee here. 

I plopped myself on the 71 and took the bus over to the Inner Sunset.  I had my book in hand as I walked in and saw maybe 8 tables or so all filled, except 2.  Grrr.  Plus there was a line of people to get their fix.

I'm poor till payday on Friday, so I decided to just get a tea as I had like 4 bucks on me and figured I might want a snack.  Seriously, I had 2 dollars and 2 dollars in change.  It's sad.

Anyway, I got up to the counter and ordered my tea.  The woman gave me a cup of hot water and I saw they had a fairly large selection of teas to choose from.  Nice!!  And to my luck, a couple had left a table just for me to grab in time before anyone else.  

I sat and read for a bit while my hot tea cooled down.  I started to eye a bagel with jam (mmm) and went to order.  I sat back down and got back to my reading when I realized after maybe 5-7 minutes that I didn't have my bagel.  Does it take that long to toast and slap jam on it??  I went to the counter and it was a bit awkward as the 2 people who might be the owners (??) seemed to be having a bit of a dispute.  The woman signaled to the guy that I was standing at the counter.  I told the guy I ordered a bagel with jam and he immediately apologized for not getting it to me sooner.  I was glad though my bagel was still warm with that yummy strawberry jam on it.

I read for another hour or so.  People seemed to arrive in waves.  The seating was pretty full until around 5ish as I'm sure people were heading home or out to have dinner.  The guy who was there behind the counter seemed friendlier than the woman.  She did pick up my plate from my table which was nice, I thought.  Two other guys took over after a while and they seemed super friendly to one customer who I imagine is a regular.

It's a nice place to hang out and read or work for a while.  Granted the space is limited.  I liked that the tables had coffee beans inside.  Fancy.  Granted I don't like the taste of coffee, but love the smell of it.

Oh man, this review's crazy long!  I'll probably pop in here again.  Maybe try a chai tea latte but from the sounds of some of the reviews here, it will be a hit or miss.  

I'll be back!!!
author: imelda j.

description:
You're perfect! Don't change a thing... 

Their organic French roast and a whole wheat bagel do me right every single time. They also have sublime loose tea and great deals on coffee by the pound (a mere $7!). And there are pretty girls who help you with your order. 

The Beanery is my version of heaven on earth.
author: carrie c.

description:
Get thee to a Beanery! 

Are you as addicted to decaf soy lattes as I am? Probably not...but boy oh boy this place sure could convert you in a jiff. They are a bit pricey but that perfect froth (which can be difficult with soy milk) is a thing of beauty worth the price. Oh cup of depth...sweet..bitter..and oh so magical..please find your way to my lips soon!
author: Natalie G.

description: Great tasting coffee for a price that doesn't put a hole in your wallet. The place is good for studying too b/c it is very quiet and they don't blast Skrillex with their speakers. For those of who you get easily distracted by internet while studying, this is the perfect place for you b/c they don't have any wifi. In case you are wondering, I got a single shot Capuccino. That totally killed my food coma after eating a heavy brunch at Art's Cafe (which I also recommend going). Datz all.
author: Mark Y.

description:
Best Coffee Ever.  

I cant compare this coffee to anything else because it would be plain wrong!  This is the *spot* that i bring all coffee afficinados and aspiring wannabees to share what i envisioned as the best coffee ever.

forget all the foo-foo flavored lattes and mochas that mask the flavor of coffee.  The sign of a great coffee shop can be seen with a simple cup of regular house coffee.  The beanery offers strong yet smooth coffee at a reasonable price (large for 1.75).

The beanery is conveniently located in the middle of a big muni transfer area (9/irving), but doesnt have a lot of seating area, no outlets nor wifi.  But nothing matters with the best coffee ever.

.... i hope i didnt over-hype, but i really like this coffee shop :]
author: kate y.

description:
Sitting a little cramped, with strange kooky woman next to me, 
But warm and enjoying my baked goodie from next door (Arizmendi's of course), 
Reading paper about tap dance street performer at Powell/Market heading off to travel the world for more pay-ful crowds, 
Being dreamy for vacation upcoming, 
Reading about Mayor Newsom in Delancey rehab, 
Being dreamy about new adventure,
Being idealistic about falling down, 
Sipping soft tasty cappuccino, 
smelling fresh roasting coffee,
Gaging a certain soon to be ex 's level of frustration from me reading him the fun things i was reading, while he's reading,
mmmm... 
it's nice, simple.
author: Today Y.

description:
First, the Beanery is not an appealing name. The first time I came here, my logic went along the lines of "man, they must have some good coffee to get away with a name like that."

They do not.

Espresso drinks seem to be a gamble... In the handful of times I've been, I've gotten some good and some awful and some meh. Very barista-dependent, which is in and of itself a good thing. But more often than not the drinks don't come out well. As for the house coffee... Let me just say no.

And then there's the weird decor of the place. It's handsome in its own right, and well-kept, don't get me wrong. But it feels like they're going for a certain kind of classy look which is much more becoming of a funeral home. I've never felt exactly welcome here, and upon reflection, I can't think of any categorical person who would.
author: Wayne W.

description:
The little roaster that could still can.  Best latte in the area.  

The staff is always super friendly, and on those (5 or 6) non-foggy frigid days in the InSet, it's a great place to sit outside, read a book, and watch the people criss-crossing 9th and Irving.

Also a great place to caffinate oneself before heading to the de Young or California Academy of Sciences so you can get your money's worth before the crowds tire you out.
author: James M.

description:
Why must Starbucks dominate every corner?!?

Like my review of Alvin's further down the Avenues by 19th, you're better off skipping S'Bux and coming here.

Beanery offers some very good organic/fair trade coffee.  The cafe setup is similar to that of most of the Royal Ground chain cafes--identical sets of tables and chairs aligned in a row.  Sit out front or by the window to get a glimpse of the bustle at 9th & Irving.  The mood is mellow, with patrons engaging in neighborly chat, focused on their work, or just taking a load off to sit back and enjoy a nice cup of coffee.  The staff seemed friendly to indifferent.  

Overall, it's standard for a cafe, but the rich coffee and high level of people watching activity (almost an essential to a cafe, in my opinion) inclined me to add an extra star.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I think myself blessed to have this cafe right on my block, and not just because the French Roast keeps me hopped up all morning like a mouthful of coca leaves, or because the owner is a daddy-hot Persian who sits on the sidewalk smoking a pipe and turning the world on with his glower. I like having it on my doorstep because there's never anywhere to sit. 

The place is jammed with addicted regulars until well past noon, so when I don't feel like elbowing myself a space in the middle of the klatsch of gabby gray-haired bear/queens that rules the roost in the mid-morning, I can just slip back to my own couch and nurse my buzz in private. Visitors from other parts of the city may find the logistics of the place more of an obstacle, but when that French Roast hits your pleasure centers, trust me, it'll feel worth it.

I stick with the drip coffee, and when it's as fresh and rich as this, it's as good as any espresso. The cafe's roaster takes up much of the space that might otherwise be devoted to seating, and most days you can watch the hot Persian roast and grind what you'll be drinking later.

Pastries are decent, but you can get better round the corner at Tart to Tart or up the block at Arizmendi. I love the baristas for the long-simmering dramas I've watched mature among them over the years, and as they do nothing more for me than hand me a cup, I am untroubled by any efficiency problems they may have. But all that's incidental next to the beans, and the Beanery's beans are good.
author: Distingué Trace S.

description: Had chi tea latte the other day. Very tasty. Love it. Also had iced coffee which was ok...
author: Jasmina T.

description:
I have been on the look out for a "single espresso for here" made perfectly within walking distance from my apartment. My recent trip to the motherland Portugal has made me addicted to finding a similar espresso. Amazingly, it has not been as easy as one would think. Starbuck's fails, obvi. I have tried Holy Gealto! up the street, it was ok..... they tried! 

 After grabbing my little espresso cup and taking a seat I took a quick smell of my black drink. *sniff* I was quickly reminded of my visit to Portugal... now if only the taste was right. Down it went and it was great! The taste was fresh and very smooth, not a "burnt taste" like others here say. I enjoyed the place and will return. They get four stars because they are missing European sugar packets, making my experience not 100%.
author: Richard M.

description:
The Beanery offers good coffee and a nice selection of whole bean coffee.  Of particular interest to me, they offer whole bean light roasted coffees.  Being a light-roast coffee type of guy in a town dominated by dark-roast coffee, this alone wins the Beanery big points in my book.

They also earn  bonus points for being the first coffee shop to open in the Inner Sunset and for their location across the street from the N-Judah stop at 9th and Irving.  

The interior of the place is nice, but I don't find it particularly comfortable for hanging out.  Accordingly, I think the Beanery works best as a cafe you walk into, order your coffee, and leave.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I have been meaning to try Beanery for-EVER now and finally just swung by on a whim early one morning this week and was pleasantly surprised with what I found.

The coffee?  Deeee-liciously deeee-lightful.  
And my favorite bakery pick?  Try the Blueberry Bran Muffin.  It's the best one I've had since Cole Valley Cafe.

This is a fantastic spot for coffee.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Katie C.

description:
Best coffee in the neighborhood (don't bother trying Cafe Gratitude's cold-pressed stuff; Canvas Cafe's is even more bullshit), hands down.  Get it to go to wander through the park, because if you get it for there, it'll (a) come in a glass cup -- people, there's a reason you use ceramic, and it's not just style (retains heat better); and (b) you'll have to drink it in the silent chamber of a caf, feeling weird if you're talking louder than a whisper.  I agree with the reviewer who compared the atmosphere to like being in church.

The three stars it gets, however, are *all* about the coffee.  Not a destination for me -- I'll save that for Bluebottle & Rtiual -- but, if I'm in the Inner Sunset, a must-stop.
author: Nori H.

description: The Organic French Roast Coffee is "To Die For." I just happened by one day and Wow! Absolutely the best coffee I have ever had!
author: Kailey W.

description:
I grabbed a coffee in here, just after lunch at Tasty Curry up the block. I liked the way it looked from out front.

Why is it so hard to make a good ice coffee? This place was fine, but nothing about said "Great Iced Joe."

Still, I may come back, because I think this may be a potential Persian owned business in need of an outing.
author: Jason R.

description:
Like my freckles, this place grew on me with time.  At first I only went there to avoid the predictability of Starbucks, yet I found the staff to be indifferent.  That is until they started to recognize me - then they slowly warmed into the friendly faces I see now who know the name of my new baby as well as my own.   

Oh - and the coffee is mmm mmm GOOD.  I buy my beans there as well as drip to-go.  I love that you fill your own drip so you can mix caf & decaf to your delight and.. they offer my fave - brown sugar.
author: Kristin S.

description:
It was cold and windy and all I wanted was a cup of tea - the Beanery made it that much better with a great variety of loose tea options. 

The gal was super friendly and helped me choose a flavor, she pulled the loose tea from the neat tea cabinets behind the counter and let me smell it. 

There's some cool decorations inside and I I also like the patio tables outside - great for people watching! 

*Cash only*
author: Gladys C.

description:
Huge shout-out for a catering-sized coffee order.  The staff was sooo over-the-top helpful and accommodating that they get my first "5-star" review. If you ever have to get boxes of coffee for an event or whatever, I'd give these folks the highest recommendation.

The coffee itself? People loved it but I'm probably the only person in SF that doesn't drink coffee so can't say...but anyone I've ever brought here loves it!
author: Steve E.

description:
This place is really good and hardly ever packed. The help is really nice. Chilling here on a sunny day is divine.
They can also make a pretty good raspberry mocha.
author: Yvonne Q.

description:
coffee - don't know, don't drink the stuff
cocoa - cr@p
staff - the mini-wager was a nice guy, can't make a cocoa to save his life.
what appeared to be the owners? some really b*tchy lady, or she was having a bad day.
outlet for laptop - NO
Seating - not so comfy short row of benches and chairs.

The whole place says "get out of here, we hate people."  But maybe that's because they have so many homeless guys wandering in... who knows.
author: Dan M.

description: gimme that caffein. good coffee. nice people. perfect location. (next door to my house)
author: Audrey K.

description: The organic french roast tastes amazing. It's a good strong roast, but not so strong that my stomach wants to do somersaults. I like it with a little milk and 2 sugars.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Hands down the best coffee in SF.  The Sumatra Mandheling is my favorite as it balances the flavor of the coffee with low acidity which makes for very easy drinking with none of that skanky aftertaste you get in lesser quality coffees.  

The pastries are usually reasonably good if you get them toward the beginning of the day, and they've got a pretty good selection of teas to choose from as well.

They sell their beans whole, or will grind them according to your specifications.  The only thing that I'm not cool with is the neat looking bins of beans on the wall that are not for sale...the only beans for sale are listed on the board above/behind the counter.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Dear Beanery,

Please, for christ's sake (or at least the sake of my pants), make the switch to a cup/lid combination that is mutually beneficial.  i haven't ever gotten a cup of coffee that didn't leak on me.  mega bummer.  and now on to the obligatory categories: so far as your coffee goes, I'll take your brand over Starbucks but only just barely.  I feel like the coffee has usually been sitting about half an hour too long.  as to espresso, if you can't handle coffee, why would i trust you behind an espresso machine? thus, no comment.  Your staff isn't the most friendly bunch on the planet, but certainly nice enough.

in summation, average marks across the board - but that lid thing just irritates me too dern much for a three star.
author: nick e.

description: Great drinks, comfy ambiance...but GO HERE BECAUSE OF THE LEMON POPPY SEED COOKIES.  They are as big as your face and will melt in your mouth.  They are amazing.
author: Elli F.

description:
I stopped in here yesterday trying to find a local coffee joint I like, and I may have found a winner.  The house coffee was pretty good, and the beans are definitely freshly roasted.  The cappuccino was actually good too, with good crema and body on the espresso and good foam (none of that dish-soap stiff nonsense).  Madeleines were only so-so, but you can't have everything.

I'd come back for an afternoon of coffee and books, but it's a little cramped for a long chat with friends.
author: Akshay S.

description: I'm always on the go and they are fast as I am predictable about what I want.  Some of the guys know me by name and they'll hand me a large cup before I give them cash.  I LOVE it!  I can drink this coffee black, which isn't always the case with other places.  I'm a fan of the roasters blend and this place is my favorite caffeine hit.
author: Amy L.

description:
lots of coffee joints to choose from in this area, and this is my favorite.
the baristas are cute and talented, the pastries hold their own against arizmendi up the street, the folks remember you and practically have your order ready the moment they see you walk through the door.
so so so sweet.  the morning gal is hot!
sometimes there is a weird shiny homeless dude out front that gives me the creeps, just sayin.
author: yayoi s.

description: Originally I planned to get breakfast at Arizmendi Bakery- sadly, they are closed on Mondays. So I kept walking a little while farther, thankfully encountering Beanery before I got to Starbucks. I got a chocolate croissant (standby, although they had numerous other pastries including vegan cookies) and a latte to go. Note to self- they don't accept credit cards! The guy at the counter was very nice in telling me this, however, and a five spot in my pocket saved the day. My latte was very rich, and the chocolate croissant had a high chocolate-to-pastry ratio (a rare occurrence), usually I have to eat the croissant carefully so that I don't finish the chocolate and end up with half of the pastry left and no desire to eat it. The shop is tiny, with only about 5 tables inside, and they don't have Sweet n Lo for some reason??
author: Amaranta C.

description: The coffee is excellent, staff is friendly and talkative  (really nice barista made mention of how it's great that I can drink 4 shots). They have a decent array of pastries, also. The place is often full, so there is rarely a lot of room to sit and it's also cash only (and I forget to hit the ATM frequently). Overall, a very consistent place to get one's caffeine fix.
author: R K.

description:
wow wow wow

the lattes here are awesome, right on par with blue bottle and slightly more mellow than peets.

a small was $2.60, a steal in SF

they pour out the foam in a heart design, always nice to start your day off with hearts!
author: Josie M.

description:
Ordered an iced latte many many times. But recently, have found it to taste a little burned, which is a major turn-off. I got their iced coffee today, and love it. Only $1.85! It makes me laugh that people still wait in line at Starbucks across the street when there's the Beanery & Dash Cafe right there (though, their frapps are really good, not gonna lie). 

There's not much sitting room, unless you share your table with a stranger. Baristas/staff are friendly. Good neighborhood spot.
author: Sarah H.

description: If you go there in the morning you can see the big cofee roasting meal going. Its an authentic, unique, and consistent! Love the experience
author: Yana L.

description: This place makes the most perfect iced mocha! Perfect pick me upper on a lazy weekday afternoon.
author: Xiaoyin W.

description: Why do these guys get good reviews? Coffee is stale and burnt, the pastries taste like day-olds from Safeway, and the service is lousy. What else can you say? I went once and definitely won't return.
author: Aaron G.

description: Walked in at 6:36 on a Sunday evening looking for dessert some coffee. While we were looking over the pastry case the clerk said, "Hurry up guys.  I'm closing in a few minutes." We decided to make his job a little easier by walking straight out the door.
author: dan d.

description: Delicious coffee, friendly staff. What more could I ask for? I guess maybe a comfier place to sit, or one of those coffee cards that gets you your 10th drink free... But that doesn't stop me from coming in almost every day :)
author: Melissa A.

description:
I love this place. I've been coming here for years, and yeah, Bex, it isn't "that" sort of place. They aren't an office space, it's a cafe. They make money by selling coffee, and a nice experience. If people are taking up tables for hours, that doesn't happen.

But, if you do want to do more than sit around working (seriously, can't people just do that at home or in an office?!) this is a great spot. The owner is very sweet and the staff are as well. Kate (the one with the tattooes) is my favorite, she only works the afternoons on weekends but she's hilarious. Cruz is also awesome, he makes the best drinks ever. Actually, all the staff here rock. I just don't know their names.

My only complaint? I wish they sold tea by the pot, not just by the cup.
author: mary g.

description:
Best coffee, the people who work there remember your drink of choice, Love it.

Being a local to the sunset area this is one of my favorite spots. I recommend a double Americano with lots of room in a small cup.... mmmm.
author: Eric T.

description:
I'll start off by saying that I'm not a big coffee drinker, or perhaps it'd be better to say I wasn't a coffee drinking prior to discovering The Beanery.   I'm feeling lazy, so instead of a fancy paragraph, I'll just give a list of the reasons I love this place:

1) The coffee is delicious.  It's fresh roasted and well... delicious.  This is the only place I can drink black coffee

b) The employees are super nice and they recognize me.  When the line is long and I'm at the rear (I know that sounds dirty but I swear it's not) they hand me my large coffee and I hand them direct change.  This really helps save time when I'm trying to catch the next train

3) ICED CAFE MOCHA!!! Holy crap!  This is a piece of art.  I'm not sure if its the coffee or the chocolate that makes this do damn delicious,  but I'm in love with this drink. 

4) Outdoor Seating, they've got it.  When I wake up on a sunny morning, I love to sit outside, drink my coffee, read and people watch.  It's right across the street from the N-Judah, so there are some (interesting) people walking around. The only minus is the outdoor chairs.  These things are so damn uncomfortable. Perhaps that's their way of getting people to rotate through the 6 chairs.

The coffee here is delicious, but not necessarily consistent.  And if consistency is what you're after there's a Starbucks right across the street from this place.  But if you want something tasty (tastier) and something local  definitely come here
author: Aaron S.

description: Gourmet coffee quick stop. The Organic French Roast was well bodied & enough to warm your senses. I wouldn't sit here to enjoy a cup with a friend, the atmosphere isn't as welcoming as mentioned in other review. Good spot to stop on the go
author: Bianca L.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop in the neighborhood. Starbcks is always over crowded and has local homeless people hanging out. The Beanery does not have the most comfortable seating, but the amibiance is relaxing and the smell of fresh coffee is great. It has a great local feel.
The staff have their quirks, but the tea selection is great. The owner is always pleasant to talk with and keeps a very clean environment. The best cap's in town! It is worth a try if in the neighborhood!
author: Kim K.

description: Randomly stopped at this place without much expectations. It turned out to be one of the best cafe in san Francisco.  I ordered a single latte and a raspberry almond bar.  They were so good together.  Their espresso tastes very similar to what I had in Italy, and they did an excellent job mixing with milk.   Two ladies working there was super friendly and nice.  I will become a regular here.
author: Sky B.

description: My son always bought his beans here and had a card for a free 10th pound, so we stopped by to use it, as he was leaving the city.  The guy at the counter was awesome and the coffee and chocolate croissant we enjoyed was great as well.  Located in a cool area of SF as well....
author: Jan M.

description:
I came with a friend to get some coffee on a Monday, and we got a latte and a cappuccino. The barista made my friend's cappuccino first, and then made my latte with the same steamed milk. As a result, my latte was way too foamy! 

I really wanted to like this place, so I'll come again in the future in the hopes that I can give a better rating.
author: Crystal L.

description: Just fell in love with this place a few weeks ago. My 5 stars is solely for the best iced mocha I've ever had :) A great place to sit down, sip some coffee and do some reading.. I love the 9th Avenuee!
author: Marlis T.

description: This is the Service I like to see when I'm ordering my coffee on an early morning.  Very friendly, cool people, great coffee, roasted fresh!
author: Brandon H.

description: The Beanery gets a 4.5. The mocha's here are fantastic and the dood who makes them is really cool. The latte's are good, but the mocha is among the best i've ever had. They also serve semifreddie's baked goods which are fantastic. Really awesome biscotti. I really like coming here because the service is so good.
author: Erik S.

description:
I've boycotted starbucks. It took me a long time, but I've finally done it and I mean to stick with it. 
So yesterday, when I was at the corner of 9th and Irving and deliberately ignoring the starbucks over there, I sauntered up to Beanery. I ordered an iced decaf soy mocha (iced because it was hot outside, decaf because I'm breasfeeding and soy because I hate cows). The place smelled amazing and when I mentioned that to the woman behind the counter, she didn't say ANYTHING. In fact, I don't think she said anything to me period. The customer service (if it could be called that) was a big turn-off.
But...I can't help but give the place four stars anyway because it was definitely one of the best iced mochas I've ever tasted (seriously only one mocha was better - at a place in Mill Valley). I could taste how fresh the espresso was and for my taste it was the perfect blend of chocolate sweetness and espresso. It was also frothy and didn't contain 90% ice - unlike starbucks. When I pay $4 for a drink, I want it to be mostly drink, not mostly ice. Incidentally - even with soy, the price for a 20oz iced mocha was less than what I'd pay for a grande mocha at Starbucks and Beanery sells my favorite vegan cookies from Alternative Baking Co. (YAY Lemon Poppyseed!)
You can definitely tell the difference between a cup of coffee made with beans roasted on site. It's hard to go back once you've tasted it. 

I'll be coming back to this place every time I'm in the area but I'm sad that the people behind the counter aren't more friendly.

***edit****I forgot to mention one huge bonus about this place. Unlike the Sbux on 19th and Irving (closest to my home) and less frequently, the one at 9th and Irving, my 14 month old daughter (in her stroller, with me) was not accosted by putrid smelling individuals trying to talk to her, get her to smile, give five, wave hello, etc. Somehow people have lost the ability to discern when it is definitely NOT ok to touch somebody else's baby. When you smell like urine and there are giant hairs growing out of the giant moles on your chin and your teeth look like they haven't seen a toothbrush in 2 years, this is NOT the right time to (even try to) touch random stranger's offspring. 
Translation: Beanery has more polite and clean patrons. For that alone, I'll keep coming back. Hopefully without a stroller soon.
author: Laura G.

description: No wifi, no compost/recycling bins... wtf.  Do they *really* want me to go to Starb*cks across the street?
author: Tom H.

description: The employees here generally are amazing. The owner leaves something to be desired in terms of being way too harsh on the people he's not paying enough to treat that way, in general. The coffee is pretty good, the food isn't good enough, and the atmosphere varies according to the clientele. Although it's nice to sit outside, it's loud, exhaust-ridden, and there are commonly rather unfriendly interlopers...
author: Tarm Y.

description: they do some great foam, and a decent espresso. 5 stars cause they even shocked me a little.
author: Zachary B.

description: I usually make a stop here to pickup a pound of organic sumatra to last a month or so. Kinda happened on this spot being it was close to Arizmendi.  I have yet to actually sitdown for coffee being the the place is usually packed.  If you enjoy a medium blend coffee you will love the sumatra here.
author: omar b.

description: There is a Beanery on Irving, which does have wifi, and still has great coffee. The almond pear bar was delicious. The service is great. I should put this under the other Beanery, but I thought I should update my other review instead...
author: Renata B.

description: Don't know what happened but their coffee isn't half as good as it used to be, with a bitter, make that acrid, aftertaste. The barristas here are nice for the most part, but I sure wish they would stop with the "ma'am."  Who likes that?
author: tess s.

description: Excellent coffee, but some of the staff will depress you.  Priced as high as the green giant around the corner.
author: Morey S.

description:
I am writing this not because I don't like the place, but in the hopes that the owner reads this posting.

Coffee/desserts/staff are great. It's the owner's sarcasm that I can't stand. True, he does greet people nicely as they walk by him outside (he often sits out there smoking a pipe), but inside, he has a real problem with a cynical attitude. 

I went in there in the morning to buy coffee & a scone & he was already out of scones at like 10am. I said, "Would it be possible for you to order a few more scones?" And he said (in a pretty nasty voice), "And are you going to guarantee me that you will come in and buy them all??" 

Weird. 

Then yesterday, we went in & my friend ordered tea. The owner took the tea bag & started to rip it open. My friend (who likes her tea weak) said, "Oh please don't put the tea bag in- I'd like to do it" and the owner says with sarcasm, "Do you want to pour your own hot water, too?"

Unnecessary rudeness and sarcasm, apparently his modus operandi. Almost makes me want to get me coffee across the street at Starbucks. Blech.
author: Dee B.

description: Super friendly, cozy spot in the inner sunset. Great coffee drinks, much better value than Starbucks across the street.
author: Sylvie S.

description: I agree with the reviewers who noted the strange layout of this place.  When it's crowded, there's literally nowhere to go unless you want to drape yourself over the coffee press and bags of coffee beans.  Luckily it wasn't crowded when I stopped in to get my mid-afternoon caffeine drip, I mean fix.    They made me a pretty latte with a milky heart swirl.   Awww, look, coffee art!  Their extensive selection of pastries looked quite delicious too.
author: Smruti S.

description: This neighborhood has quality coffee and let's be honest, it is all about supporting the local coffee shops.  Super flavorful, as oppose to the awful Starbucks!!!  They have sweet and low, aka the pink pkgs, which makes the experience so much better!  Never tried the pastries, yet they have seating in front.  On a sunny day, things couldn't be better.
author: Nicole F.

description: Used to be my fav. Now OK due to rude staff. Ruder owner. Inconsistent coffee. Nice place to sit inside. Better quality to be had across the street at StarBucks. Arizmendi has better coffee and pastries. Other store much better.
author: YearOf M.

description: Wow! Amazing coffee, worthy of the drive into San Francisco to get!!
author: J R.

description: Good cupsa joe are found at te Beanery. The staff is nice. The tables are awesome due to the readily-viewable beans (enclosed by glass). Indoor and outdoor seating. Good scones here, too.
author: Dan S.

description: Ran into the owner today... he also ran his mouth at the employees. They were so nice too! So sad... yet I still return for the fair trade organics.
author: Teresa Y.

description: I usually get coffee to go here; their lattes are fantastic. Not bitter, and if you have flavoring added, they add just the right amount so it is not too sweet. They are also quick and efficient  if you are in a hurry, while still being friendly. I like the basic (non-"artisan") feel to the place as well.
author: Caroline C.

description: Great coffee. Bonus: the dude who makes it is cool. F**k starbucks.
author: Sven S.

description: Best neighborhood cafe - have been coming here for 3.5 years.  Perfect, creamy lattes.  Freshly roasted coffee.  Scones & bagels are also excellent.  The guys always remember my order.  The owner always offers a warm smile & greetings as he smokes his pipe outside or assists inside.    Good atmosphere with locals greeting each other.
author: Anita K.

description: For all Java Junkies: this is the place to mainline hardcore!!  Strong coffee without the bitter aftertaste found in the brew of some of the more established joints. Eclectic group of regulars from the hood: from UCSF grads to 9th Ave politicos. I walked in one morning to find a big birthday sign and a crew dominating 4 tables, celebrating their friend's turn around the sun cafaholic style. For those not interested in the "high," go with the organic decaf. Great place to make a morning pit-stop.
author: Johnny C.

description: Good coffee shops are surprisingly hard to find in this area, so score one for the Beanery. The minute you walk in the door, the coffee aroma is amazing. The coffee and lattes are great, and the service is pleasant. My dad and I have made a habit of stopping here after lunch to grab a quick coffee and a cookie. The bad thing is that there are only a few seats - I've never seen an open table. I would just plan on some tasty coffee to go. If only you could take that coffee aroma with you...
author: Teresa S.

description: I like this place. The barista with the ponytail is funny. They all make really cute designs in the foam. For such a small store, it's warm and fun to hang out in, with interesting people wandering in and out. Much more laid-back and interesting than the bright shiny stressed-out S***cks down the street. The coffee is good. Maybe not the very best in the city but it is definitely good and certainly on par with the burnt French roach favored by many other places in town.
author: p v.

description: The best Beanery is located in Eugene, OR, but this one is alright too ( I assume there is no affiliation between the two, but I like this one for having the same name as my old haunt). At least it's not a Starbucks. The mocha I had was nice and I am happy to find out that they do the fair trade, organic thing. The seating isn't very comfy, but they have an awesome antique roaster contraption (I guess that's what it is) as decore. Stop here for a pick-me-up while you're shopping the gifty shops around 9th and Irving.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Soy latte wins. It's all I get, it's all I need. It's my favorite latte in the city. The service is always prompt and nice. The flavor is always deep, just the right sweet, just the right bitter. By the end of my, for lack of a better word, affair (because it's so good, you might just be cheating on someone, the amount of enjoyment this little drink provides) I am all warm and toasty, my hands thoroughly warmed by the hot beverage, my stomach thoroughly filled with caffeinated energy froth. PLUS I can get one of my favorite scones from Arizmendi just up the street. Ahhh, near perfection, how I love thee.
author: Shannon F.

description: Good location, as it was directly behind my bus stop that I used to take. I would go in for their nonfat hot chocolate in the AM and as it was not the greatest cup of hot cocoa, it was well worth the price.
author: Janel Y.

description: I had a latte. It was good. very limited seating
author: harjit c.

description: Mmm. Very hot, organic french roast. Perfect for the foggy Sunset weather,and owned by a very nice man.
author: Kirsten B.

description: The Beanery is a place where you drink coffee, not where you go to look like you're a coffee drinker. They don't have comfy couches, board games, or lame "world music" playing. Instead, they focus on beans: they actually roast their own coffee, resulting in consistently delicious coffee, frothy espressos with just the right amount of bitterness, and, I hear, the best soy lattes in San Francisco.
author: Ben P.

description: Cute place. I've only had tea here, and I guess it's hard to screw bag tea up, so my review will be short. The barista was really friendly, and the tables are attractive and nice. I've Muni-ed and walked by this place hundreds of times and wanted to go in--the location is great and the people reading papers at the tables outside look really idyllic. I'll be back.
author: Ramon E.

description: Best espresso in the city.  Best coffee in the neighborhood, and perhaps best in the city.  Regulars are recognized by the owner and employees, which is always nice.  He has to deal with a Starbucks within view, but he has loyal customers like me that swear six ways from Sunday that his goods are far superior.
author: Patrick L.

description: I have had my share of lattes at many different cafes here in The City, and Beanery is one of my favorites. I always have my single lattes with a bit of honey and some cocoa powder and I'm good to go. And if you get there at the right time, you'll catch the owner roasting the coffee beans with that beautiful antique roaster on site.
author: Jen L.

description: I used to live in the inner sunset and this was my favorite cafe.   The people are friendly, the coffee rocks, and the cafe is small and cozy.  The only downside is that it's often hard to find an empty seat.
author: Stefani D.

description: Sometimes it takes two seconds to finish in a Starbucks...take an extra step, turnaround, cross the street and get a "ristretto" (not a 'solo') in a warm and friendly atmosphere.
author: Dario B.

description: This place is REALLY WEIRD. There is usually this guy who sits outside for hours with a parrot or something on his shoulder. So strange. Lots of bearded, philosophy major clientele, it appears. I used to go here when I was really little, and I remember they have cool photography on the walls, like this one of a huge wave hitting a lighthouse.
author: O K.

description: I like this place. You can just get what you want, no frills, the service is good, and the coffee is very good. You can almost always get a table, and the people seem good natured and friendly. I got a carrot muffin this morning that was good, the french roast coffee was most excellent, and the fact that a refill was just 50 cents was totally tubular. Better than the 'bucks, people.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
A very good coffee shop/cafe. Super good lattes with very friendly service and the prices are reasonable especially for the quality of the coffees you are drinking. The staff are owner with offer you a warm smile. It's a place you can feel relaxed and comfortable in. And I don't think they mind you sneaking in pastries from Arizmendi Bakery right up the street. Just order a large coffee and be kind with a tip.

Until they prove otherwise they get five stars.
author: Steven P.

description: I love this place! The staff are always really friendly and have gotten used to my orders and usually finish my sentences. The only minor thing that would make this place better is big comfy sofas/chairs inside... but otherwise usually a lot of seating inside and outside. Great place to people watch right at the heart of the inner sunset.
author: Billie S.

description: Love to come here especially after I'm disappointed by the crappy Starbucks on the opposite corner.  I usually go for the Soy Latte.  The beans are fresh and roasty, and they even finish off the foam on top with an artistic touch.  You can feel the love compared to the baristas at Sbux who tend to move like molasses and pour watered down beverages.
author: Brandon C.

description: Mmmmm...: Took Mike and Serena here for a coffee break after a hike up to Grand View Park/Moraga Hill, and they enjoyed the coffee and even the organic pistaschio cookie. (Normally, I don't care for organic, but this was good!) I have also been there for writing practice...and loved people-watching from the rows of tables lined up along the wall facing the roaster.
author: Jo S.

description: Every once and awhile you will get that grumpy short-haired girl behind the counter but for the most part service is always friendly and the iced mocha, my personal fave, is the best. cash only, but if you love this place you already know that.
author: courtney b.

description: Is there anything better on a hot morning than a cold, strong, iced coffee... especially with some pastries from Arizmendi down the street?
author: Jordan Y.

description: This is a really good place to get a good cup of coffee and they know how to make a great latte.  I buy my beans here, I love the Columbian and the Viennese, and you can get organic fair trade beans as well.  They also roast their beans in the shop, very cool roasting machine. You can get a card for frequent buyers and after you buy 10 lbs., you get one free. Great deal if you can keep track of your card.  The employees are great, but the owner can be a bit uptight. I think he drinks too much coffee. I definitely recommend for the coffee, but go up the street to Arizmendi for a treat.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
best tasting coffee in the sunset.  if you want a plush chair and couch to sit on, go to the chain... but if you wan great coffee in a great shop, go here.  small tables are available, and are comfortable.  good selection of teas, chai, hot and cold drinks, and pastries.  good servers who know how to make what you order, and you don't have to say wierd names or do it in a specific order.

good tasting coffee roasted well, no bitterness, fresh tasting and not too oily.
author: Bruce W.

description:
waaaaayyyyyy tooooooo sloooooooow

i went in a couple different saturdays. 3 people working the front, 3 people in line and somehow it took 15 minutes to get everyone taken care of?!

dont go here if you need to be anywhere anytime soon

coffee is good, but there are a few other options in the area that are as good and not serving at a turtle pace.
author: Christine B.

description:
This is my first review, so bear with me.

The first star is because the lattes here are great, the milk is smooth and creamy, naturally sweet. Which is how a latte is supposed to be, not an overly bubbly mess of hot milk.

The second star is because it is a locally owned business, though the guy that seems to be in charge gets a little tense. But again, it is a locally owned business, and they roast their own beans!

The third star is because the prices are so reasonable. Many other places charge more for a lesser quality cup 'o joe, and about three bucks for a double latte is more than fair!

The fourth star is because the people that work here seem to really know and care about coffee. or at least know what makes each drink what it is, and do it correctly. 

They WOULD get a fifth star for their female barista, because she's hot and funny, and I like her tattoos. But that has nothing to do with coffee.
author: Mitsy P.

description: I love the Beanery.  The coffee is so good, and the owner is such a great guy.
author: ms.maiplum t.

description: Nice. I get to buy pounds of good whole bean coffee for 7-8 bucks. Can't ask for much more than that.
author: anon m.

description: Small, good coffee and drinks. The coffee is serve-it-yourself. I'm not sure what else I need to say. :-)
author: Joseph H.

description: Having just recently moved to this hood, finding a friendly neighborhood coffee shop was a top priority and Beanery has certainly wooed me!  Not only is the coffee delicious (I especially recommend the iced coffee), but the staff is friendly and extremely attentive.  After frequenting the shop only a few times, I was already seen as a regular, with my order ready by the time I get up to the counter.  The prices are also extremely reasonable, with a large iced ringing up at a respectable $1.85.  Some slight downsides include cash only and some cramped seating, but neither of these are able to outweigh the great cup 'o joe!
author: Liz Y.

description:
Whoah!  First time visitor to the Beanery this weekend Sunday.  Who is openly depressed cashier who was completely dead-panned, rude and near hostile?  If she's the owener, give-up, sell-out now.  If she's his wife, good luck buddy, what a b-otch.  

The whole coffee experience was ruined because of her.  

On the otherhand...the *only* reason I;ll go back is to point her out to my friends.
author: Marc L.

description: I love their lattes! Excellent espresso and friendly baristas! The cafe itself is quite small. Not good for studying or getting work done, but ok for reading a novel or the daily paper.
author: Kelsie L.

description: The lady was rude at the register.  Also, that was the worst latte ever.  I was in a desperate need of coffee...was so tired. I found the good review on yelp and went to check it out. I was only able to drink two sips and dump the rest.  I have no idea why it was so bad.  I didn't appreciate the lady and her attitude.  There are other better coffee shops with better coffee.
author: S. L.

description: good good fair trade organic coffee!  prices are not obnoxiously high for the high quality joe you get there.  not a lot of seating, but i like to grab and go anyway.  the place is cute though, so it's not a bad place to hang out. they don't play music in there, you can like or not like that. good good coffee.  and chai tea.  and they have mate drinks that i'm excited about.  good good caffeine fix.  good.
author: Monk R.

description: Good coffee.   Some baked goods are $1 after 4PM - quite a deal.   I personally like the coffee + baked goods from Arizmendi combination.   Friendly and courteous staff / owner.
author: M B H.

description: very cute coffee shop with extremely nice (and French!) employees/owners. their coffee is very good, especially the roaster's blend. I have also had a vanilla latte here which was fantastic. Haven't tried the pastries yet but they look delicious. Cozy place to grab a cup of coffee and relax on your lunch break.
author: Yasmine A.

description: I like this place.  I really do.  It has the cozy, non-Starbucksy coffee shop feel, the coffee is reasonably priced, and the people who work there are warm and genuine.
author: Insta G.

description: It's really too bad that independent neighborhood coffee places like this don't realize what's most important...  A good cup of coffee.  I've tried both the main location and the annex on the corner of 7th and Irving and the coffee tastes burnt and watery.  You may hate them and all they stand for, but Starbucks at least has a consistent high quality product, so I go there instead.
author: robert a.

description: Though the coffee is good, the owner is rude and disrespectful towards his employees. He has a bad vibe and I always get scared when pass him by. Very sad, but I'm never coming back.
author: katie m.
